action.action-desc: Ms. Pingree (for herself, Mr. Cohen, Mr. Lipinski, and Ms. Slaughter) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to allow for the personal importation of safe and affordable drugs from approved pharmacies in Canada.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Safe and Affordable Drugs from Canada Act of 2017.

section.header: Safe and affordable drugs from Canada
section.text: Chapter VIII of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 381 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Importation by individuals of prescription drugs from Canada

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this section, the Secretary shall promulgate regulations permitting individuals to safely import into the United States a prescription drug described in subsection (b).
A prescription drug described in this subsection—

subparagraph.text: is purchased from an approved Canadian pharmacy;
is dispensed by a pharmacist licensed to practice pharmacy and dispense prescription drugs in Canada;
is purchased for personal use by the individual, not for resale, in quantities that do not exceed a 90-day supply;
is filled using a valid prescription issued by a physician licensed to practice in a State in the United States; and
has the same active ingredient or ingredients, route of administration, dosage form, and strength as a prescription drug approved by the Secretary under chapter V; and
a controlled substance (as defined in section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 802));
a biological product (as defined in section 351 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 262));
an infused drug (including a peritoneal dialysis solution);
an intravenously injected drug;
a drug that is inhaled during surgery;
a parenteral drug;
a drug manufactured through one or more biotechnology processes, including—

clause.text: a therapeutic synthetic peptide product of not more than 40 amino acids;
a monoclonal antibody product for in vivo use; and

subparagraph.text: a drug required to be refrigerated at any time during manufacturing, packing, processing, or holding; or
a photoreactive drug.

paragraph.text: In this section, an approved Canadian pharmacy is a pharmacy that—

subparagraph.text: is located in Canada; and
that the Secretary certifies—

clause.text: is licensed to operate and dispense prescription drugs to individuals in Canada; and

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall publish on the Internet Web site of the Food and Drug Administration a list of approved Canadian pharmacies, including the Internet Web site address of each such approved Canadian pharmacy, from which individuals may purchase prescription drugs in accordance with subsection (a).
To be an approved Canadian pharmacy, the Secretary shall certify that the pharmacy—

subparagraph.text: has been in existence for a period of at least 5 years preceding the date of such certification and has a purpose other than to participate in the program established under this section;
operates in accordance with pharmacy standards set forth by the provincial pharmacy rules and regulations enacted in Canada;

has processes established by the pharmacy, or participates in another established process, to certify that the physical premises and data reporting procedures and licenses are in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, and has implemented policies designed to monitor ongoing compliance with such laws and regulations;

conducts or commits to participate in ongoing and comprehensive quality assurance programs and implements such quality assurance measures, including blind testing, to ensure the veracity and reliability of the findings of the quality assurance program;
agrees that laboratories approved by the Secretary shall be used to conduct product testing to determine the safety and efficacy of sample pharmaceutical products;
has established, or will establish or participate in, a process for resolving grievances and will be held accountable for violations of established guidelines and rules;
does not resell products from online pharmacies located outside Canada to customers in the United States; and
meets any other criteria established by the Secretary.
